title: Barbarians Marching to the West

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of oil paint, with frottage, wiping, and scraping, on tan wove paper, laid down on cardboard.

artist_display:
Max Ernst
American and French, born Germany, 1891-1976
medium_display: Oil paint, with frottage, wiping, and scraping, on tan wove paper, laid down on cardboard
inscriptions: Signed recto, lower right, in brush and gray oil paint: "max ernst"; inscribed verso, upper left, in pen and black ballpoint pen: "Jan Hubert/5688"; lower right, in pen and black ballpoint pen: "34063 Cologne"; sticker verso: "DU /1701"
credit_line: Gift of Dorothy Braude Edinburg to the Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection
publication_history:
Werner Spies, Max Ernst, Werke: 1929–1938 (Menil Foundation/DuMont Buchverlag, 1979), p. 346, no. 2230.

Suzanne Folds McCullagh (ed.), Drawings in Dialogue: Old Master Through Modern, The Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection, exh. cat. (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 2006), p. 209, cat. 156 (ill.).
exhibition_history:
Cologne, Galerie Der Spiegel, "Max Ernst: Neun Bilder," 1961.

Munich, Haus der Kunst, "Max Ernst," Feb. 17-Apr. 29, 1979, p. 308, cat. 249; also Berlin, Nationalgalerie, May 10–July 15, 1979.

Stuttgart, Württembergischer Kunstverein, 1900–1945, "Künstler in Deutschland: Individualismus und Tradition," Sept. 18–Nov. 9, 1986.

Boston, Museum of Fine Arts, Prized Possessions: European Paintings from Private Collections of Friends of the Museum of Fine Arts, June 17–Aug. 16, 1992, cat. 48, pl. 151.

Art Institute of Chicago, "Drawings in Dialogue: Old Master Through Modern, The Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection," June 3–July 30, 2006, p. 209, cat. 156 (ill.).
provenance_text: Galerie Der Spiegel, Cologne, by 1961.  Galerie Thomas Borgmann, Cologne.  Galerie Dieter Brusberg, Hanover, by 1979 [Spies 1979].  Sold, Christie’s, London, Mar. 30, 1987, lot 35, to Dorothy Braude Edinburg, Brookline, MA; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2013.
